Finding your way around Mars

The first step in this activity is to change the view in Google Earth, to Mars.

  • This can be done by going to View >Explore >Mars or by clicking the[[{"attributes": {"alt": "space_GE.jpg", "style": "float: none; height: 21px; width: 27px; ", "class": "media-image small asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_preview", "type": "media", "fid": "625"}]]symbol and choosing 'Mars'. 

Finding impact craters

In order to find craters in Google Mars, you can search for a particular crater using the 'Fly To' box, together with the name of the crater, or its coordinates.  You can zoom in or out of the image by using the controls, and you can drag the image by using either the controls or your mouse.

To help familiarise yourself with Google Mars, try the following exercise:

  • In the 'Fly To' box, enter the coordinates: 49.8S, 4.6W. You will now fly to this location which is the site of an impact crater on Mars, named 'Roddenberry crater' after the creator of Star Trek, Gene Roddenberry. 
  • How many other craters can you see on top of the Roddenberry crater? 
  • Using the measure tool [[{"attributes": {"alt": "Measure_GE.jpg", "style": "float: none; height: 24px; width: 30px; ", "class": "media-image small asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_preview", "type": "media", "fid": "622"}]], measure the diameter of the Rodenberry crater
  • Now find the position of the ‘Bond’ crater on Mars by using the 'Fly To' box. Zoom in on this area once it has been pinpointed.
  • Using the measure tool [[{"attributes": {"alt": "Measure_GE.jpg", "style": "float: none; height: 24px; width: 30px; ", "class": "media-image small asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_preview", "type": "media", "fid": "622"}]], measure the diameter of the Bond crater
  • In the 'Fly To' box, enter the coordinates: 14.6S, 82.9W. This crater is called the 'Odd Crater'. Zoom in on this crater- why do you think it has this name?

Comparing Mars craters with Earth craters

Zoom in/out of Google Mars until your window is filled with a Google Mars image.  Look at the distribution of impact craters in this image and answer the following questions: 

  • How does it compare to a similar image on Google Earth? Are there similar numbers of craters?
  • What factors would affect the number of craters that we can see both on Mars and Earth?
  • What other features can be seen on the surface of Mars?
  • Do you see any evidence for plate tectonics on Mars?
  • Do you see any evidence for water on Mars?

Finding your way around the Moon

The first step in this activity is to change the view in Google Earth, to the Moon.

  • This can be done by going to View >Explore >Moon or by clicking the[[{"attributes": {"alt": "space_GE.jpg", "style": "float: none; height: 21px; width: 27px; ", "class": "media-image small asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_preview", "type": "media", "fid": "625"}]]symbol and choosing 'Moon'. 
  • In the 'Fly To' box, enter the 'Sea of Tranquility'. You will now fly to this location which was the site of the first manned mission to the Moon by the Apollo 11 team. 
  • Enter the coordinates: 0.8N, 23.5 E in the 'Fly To' box. You are now centered upon the actual Moon landing site. 

Impact!

Three impact craters around the landing site of the Apollo 11 mission were named after the crew members - Armstrong, Collins and Aldrin.

  • See if you can find these craters in the area where Apollo 11 landed - you can do this by either zooming into the landing region and reading the crater labels, or by searching for them in the 'Fly To' box. 
  • Using the measure tool [[{"attributes": {"alt": "Measure_GE.jpg", "style": "float: none; height: 24px; width: 30px; ", "class": "media-image small asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_preview", "type": "media", "fid": "622"}]], measure the diameter of the 3 craters:
 Crater Name  Crater Diameter (km)
 Armstrong  
 Collins  
 Aldrin  

Using the 'Fly To' search box and the information below, find the following lunar impact craters and fill out the results table. 

 Crater Name
  Coordinates  Diameter (km)
 Oppenheimer - one of the largest lunar impact craters known, this crater is fairly difficult to see. Zoom out to see the rim of the crater.
 35.2S, 166.3W
  
   13.1N, 61.7E
  
 Tycho - some scientists believe that the asteroid which caused this crater was part of a much larger asteroid which broke up in the asteroid belt 100 million years ago. It's believed that another piece from this break-up went on to hit the Earth 65 million years ago in Mexico, causing the death of the dinosaurs. However, this is open to discussion as scientists are not completely sure of the composition of these impactors.     

Who's the oldest?

We are now going to compare the numbers of craters at different locations on the Moon to help us draw conclusions on the age of the rocks on the Moon. 

  • Fly to the coordinates 60 32 19S, 07 020 31E and zoom into an eye altitude of ~1000km (the eye altitude is given in the lower right hand corner of the Google Earth window).

You are now looking at part of the lunar highlands region. 

  • What do you notice about the number density of craters in this region?
  • How does this compare to the numbers of impact craters which we see on Earth?
  • Why is there a difference between the numbers of craters which we see on Earth and the Moon? (Hint: Think about what Earth has that the Moon doesn't..)

Look at the Clavius crater (just to the left).

  • How big is the crater?
  • What do you notice inside the crater? 

Now fly to the Sea of Tranquility. 

  • What do you notice about the number density of craters in this region?
  • How does this compare to the number density of craters in the lunar highlands?
  • Thinking about your answer to the question above, which area do you think is older, the seas or the lunar highlands? Explain your reasoning.
und.safe_value:
Finding your way around the Moon

The first step in this activity is to change the view in Google Earth, to the Moon.

  • This can be done by going to View >Explore >Moon or by clicking the symbol and choosing 'Moon'. 
  • In the 'Fly To' box, enter the 'Sea of Tranquility'. You will now fly to this location which was the site of the first manned mission to the Moon by the Apollo 11 team. 
  • Enter the coordinates: 0.8N, 23.5 E in the 'Fly To' box. You are now centered upon the actual Moon landing site. 

Impact!

Three impact craters around the landing site of the Apollo 11 mission were named after the crew members - Armstrong, Collins and Aldrin.

  • See if you can find these craters in the area where Apollo 11 landed - you can do this by either zooming into the landing region and reading the crater labels, or by searching for them in the 'Fly To' box. 
  • Using the measure tool , measure the diameter of the 3 craters:
 Crater Name  Crater Diameter (km)
 Armstrong  
 Collins  
 Aldrin  

Using the 'Fly To' search box and the information below, find the following lunar impact craters and fill out the results table. 

 Crater Name
  Coordinates  Diameter (km)
 Oppenheimer - one of the largest lunar impact craters known, this crater is fairly difficult to see. Zoom out to see the rim of the crater.
 35.2S, 166.3W
  
   13.1N, 61.7E
  
 Tycho - some scientists believe that the asteroid which caused this crater was part of a much larger asteroid which broke up in the asteroid belt 100 million years ago. It's believed that another piece from this break-up went on to hit the Earth 65 million years ago in Mexico, causing the death of the dinosaurs. However, this is open to discussion as scientists are not completely sure of the composition of these impactors.     

Who's the oldest?

We are now going to compare the numbers of craters at different locations on the Moon to help us draw conclusions on the age of the rocks on the Moon. 

  • Fly to the coordinates 60 32 19S, 07 020 31E and zoom into an eye altitude of ~1000km (the eye altitude is given in the lower right hand corner of the Google Earth window).

You are now looking at part of the lunar highlands region. 

  • What do you notice about the number density of craters in this region?
  • How does this compare to the numbers of impact craters which we see on Earth?
  • Why is there a difference between the numbers of craters which we see on Earth and the Moon? (Hint: Think about what Earth has that the Moon doesn't..)

Look at the Clavius crater (just to the left).

  • How big is the crater?
  • What do you notice inside the crater? 

Now fly to the Sea of Tranquility. 

  • What do you notice about the number density of craters in this region?
  • How does this compare to the number density of craters in the lunar highlands?
  • Thinking about your answer to the question above, which area do you think is older, the seas or the lunar highlands? Explain your reasoning.

Introductory information

For this activity, you will be measuring the intensity of the comparison star and supernova in the data files for the galaxy M100. These are labelled in the image below:
[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_preview","fid":"643","attributes":{"alt":"SN_IA_image.jpg","class":"media-image medium asset_lightbox","height":"174","style":"float: none; height: 174px; width: 250px; ;;;","typeof":"foaf:Image","width":"250"}}]]

Below are the values for the magnitudes of the standard star in each filter. For this activity you only have the data files in the R filter, so you only need to look at the R magnitude value for the comparison star:
[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_preview","fid":"644","attributes":{"alt":"SN_IA_excel.jpg","class":"media-image medium asset_lightbox","height":"71","id":"1","style":"float: none; height: 71px; width: 250px; ;;;","typeof":"foaf:Image","width":"250"}}]]

Activity instructions....

1. Open the photometry spreadsheet, ‘Photometry.xls’. Copy the R magnitude of the standard star as given above into the photometry spreadsheet into the relevant cell (R Mag).

2. The next step is to use SalsaJ to measure the intensity, or pixel counts in your FT image for the comparison star. To do this, open SalsaJ and go to: Analyse > Photometry Settings. Enter the aperture radius as 15 in the star radius box, as shown here. [[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_preview","fid":"645","attributes":{"alt":"SN_IA_radius.jpg","class":"media-image medium asset_lightbox","height":"86","id":"2","style":"float: none; height: 86px; width: 250px; ;;;","typeof":"foaf:Image","width":"250"}}]]

3. Now go to Analyse > Photometry. A pop-up box will appear, with the photometry results in it.

4. Click on the comparison star to obtain the intensity value, and then enter this value in the relevant cell in the photometry spreadsheet (R  Count).

5. Now, ensuring that you use the same star radius aperture value of 15, find the intensity value for the supernova in your image and enter it into the spreadsheet in order for the magnitude to be calculated. Make a note of the magnitude value for the supernova in the table below.

6. Repeat steps 4-5 for all the data files, for each date, and make a note of the magnitudes of the supernova in the table below.

(Occassionally, SalsaJ returns zero values for the intensity of objects - if this happens when you are measuring the intensity of your supernova in any of the images, close the image and just use the remaining ones for your plot.)

 FITS file name Day of observationSupernova magnitude
 M100_R1.fits 1 
 M100_R2.fits 3 
 M100_R3.fits 16 
 M100_R4.fits 25 
 M100_R5.fits 59 
 M100_R6.fits 103 


7. Open a new worksheet in Excel

8. Enter the values for the day of observation and magnitudes into this new Excel worksheet. (The day of observation was found by counting the number of days from the date that the first FITS file was taken. The dates for each image can be found in the FITS file header, which can be viewed in SalsaJ by going to Image > Show Info... )

9. Plot a graph with the day of observation on the x axis and the magnitude values on the y axis. When you plot your graph, make sure that the y axis is reversed - to do this, plot the graph and then double click on the y axis values. In the pop-up window that appears, select Scale > Values in reverse order. Select appropriate values for the minimum and maximum y values so that your curve covers the plotting area.

A typical supernova light curve looks like the one below:

und.value: archive

Exoplanets are planets orbiting stars other than the Sun. A small percentage of exoplanets have orbits inclined in such a way that from our line of site, the planet blocks some light from the star on its path around the star. This causes us on Earth to perceive that the star has dimmed slightly, by at most 1-2%. Over the course of transit, the light output of the star can be measured and plotted, producing a graph that normally looks something like this:

[[{"attributes": {"alt": "Exoplanet Transit", "style": "margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; height: 404px; width: 450px; ", "class": "media-image medium_large asset_lightbox", "rel": "asset_lightbox", "typeof": "foaf:Image"}, "view_mode": "media_large", "type": "media", "fid": "953"}]]

With Agent Exoplanet, you get to investigate a transit of a known exoplanet. Data of a transit of Planet 1234 has been taken for you and the star that Planet 1234 orbits was imaged 5678 times over the course of 5 hours. You can use the Agent Exoplanet web interface to measure the brightness of Planet 1234’s star in 10 or more images. Other citizen scientists around the world will be participating in the project, so many measurements will be made and averaged together

To measure the brightness of a star, you can use the Agent Exoplanet interface to place and fit a circle around the star, and then the software counts the values of all the pixels within that circle. Because the atmosphere and other factors can vary from exposure to exposure, we have to compare our star’s brightness to the brightness of another star or stars in the image.

The Agent Exoplanet interface divides the brightness of the planet’s star by the brightness of the comparison star or stars you choose. Good choices are stars that appear to be of similar size and brightness to the target star. This process eliminates variations in the brightness that are caused by the factors mentioned above, and gives a more true picture of how the brightness of the star is changing. The more comparison stars you use, the more accurate your results will be, because some stars in the frame will be variable themselves, and may not be good comparison stars. If you use different comparisons to other people it will make the results even more accurate. The sky conditions change in the time between each image being taken. We use the comparison stars and the blank sky measurements to reduce the effect of this change.

If the results you and others get are reasonably accurate, we should be able to see a transit curve on the graph (similar to the one above) on the results page of Agent Exoplanet. At the beginning of the data, the star is bright, then the brightness goes down quickly as the planet moves in front of the star. The star maintains a lower level of brightness as long as the planet is in front of it, and then quickly goes back up as the planet moves out of transit.

title: Measure the diameter of the Sun

und.value:
Introduction

The Sun moves across the sky at a constant rate because of the rotation of the Earth. By measuring how fast the Sun moves you can work out how big the Sun appears in the sky. All you need are some household items and about 20 minutes on a sunny day.

 

Full Description

Creaing a Solar Reflector

  1. Cut a small hole in the centre of the piece of thick paper.
  2. Tape the paper with the hole to the front of your mirror. Ensure that the hole is over your mirror, covering up nearly all of the reflective surface.
  3. Tape the mirror to the tripod, so that the mirror faces up.
  4. If you don’t have a tripod, put plasticine/playdough on the floor in an L-shape (as demonstrated in the photograph below) and embed the block on it so that the mirror is at about a 40-degree angle (facing the Sun).
  5. This is your solar reflector. Stand it up and make sure it is stable and will not move during the experiment. If it does move you will have to start all over again!screen up and make sure it cannot move during the experiment - if it does move you will have to start all over again.

 

[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_small","fid":"1380","link_text":null,"attributes":{"height":"144","width":"144","class":"media-image media-element file-media-small","id":"1"}}]][[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_small","fid":"1382","link_text":null,"attributes":{"height":"144","width":"144","class":"media-image media-element file-media-small","id":"1"}}]][[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_small","fid":"1384","link_text":null,"attributes":{"height":"144","width":"144","style":"width: 144px; height: 144px;","class":"media-image media-element file-media-small","id":"1"}}]][[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_small","fid":"1383","link_text":null,"attributes":{"height":"144","width":"144","class":"media-image media-element file-media-small","id":"1"}}]]

From the left: A small mirror, a lump of plasticine, a square of paper with a small hole, a reflected image of the sun.
 

[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_large","fid":"1381","link_text":null,"attributes":{"class":"media-image media-element file-media-large","id":"2"}}]]

The assembled solar reflector.

Using your Solar Reflector

  1. Angle the solar reflector so that Sun is reflected onto the screen.
  2. Trace around the image of the Sun on the screen.
  3. Start your stopwatch.
  4. Wait until the Sun has moved to just outside the circle you drew.
  5. Note the time on the stopwatch and reset
  6. Repeat steps 2 - 5 a few times (repeat 3-4 times for more accurate results).
  7. Enter your results into the table below and take the mean average duration of all your timings (in seconds).
Time 1 Time 2 Time 3 Average Duration
       

 

Discussion and Results

What you have been doing is measuring how long it takes the Sun to move a distance equal to its own diameter across the sky. The Sun will take 24 hours to travel 360 degrees, all the way around the sky, and return to the same position it was in on the previous day.

The speed the Sun travels at is: 

360 degrees / 24hours = 360 deg/(24x60) minutes = 0.25 deg per minute = 0.00416 degrees per second or 1/240 degs per second

1. Now, calculate the size of the Sun as an angle: 

Average duration (in seconds) × 1/240 (degrees per second) = _______________ degrees

Congratulations, you have calculated the angular size of the Sun!

 

Calculate the physical size of the Sun

1. You can now use your value for the angular size of the Sun to calculate the physical size of the Sun. Your number for angular size converted into radians × distance from Earth to the Sun = size of the Sun

Angular size × (π/180) × 149 598 000 km = _______________ km

 

Congratulations, you have measured and calculated the diameter of the Sun in miles/kilometers!
und.summary: The Sun moves across the sky at a constant rate because of the rotation of the Earth. By measuring how fast the Sun moves you can work out how big the Sun appears in the sky. All you need are some household items and about 20 minutes on a sunny day.

und.value:
• Students will understand the fixed speed of the Sun as it appears to travel across our sky.
  • Students will learn how to measure the movement of the Sun across the sky and use their results to calculate the angular and physical size of the Sun.
  • Students will develop an understanding of the scale of the Sun compared to the Earth and the Moon.

und.value:
For this activity you will need the following apparatus:

•    A small mirror

•    A piece of thick paper to cover your mirror

•    A tripod or a lump of Plasticine or playdough

•    Something to use as a screen (a big sheet of white paper with a cardboard backing will do)

•    A pencil or marker pen which will write on the screen

•    Masking/electrical/duct tape

•    A stop watch

Background Information

The Sun is the centre of our Solar System, provided all of the light and heat needed to support all living things on our planet. Our lives are dominated by the movement of the Earth relative to the Sun, we use these movements to measure time: one day is the length of a full rotation of the Earth on its own axis and one year is a full orbit of the Earth around the Sun. However, many people do not possess an accurate idea of the scale of the Sun relative to the Earth.  

 

It takes 24 hours for the Sun to travel 360 degrees, all the way around the sky and return to the same position it was in the previous day. The speed the Sun travels at is: 

360 degrees / 24hours = 360 deg/(24x60) minutes = 0.25 deg per minute = 0.00416 degrees per second or 1/240 degs per second

name: egomez

und.value:
Have you ever wondered what happens to the different stars in the night sky as they get older? This activity lets you explore the life-cycle of stars.

Interactive life-cycle

Star in a Box is an interactive webapp which animates stars with different starting masses as they change during their lives. Some stars live fast-paced, dramatic lives, others change very little for billions of years. The webapp visualises the changes in mass, size, brightness and temperature for all these different stages.

[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_large","fid":"1400","attributes":{"class":"media-image","id":"2","typeof":"foaf:Image"}}]]

Classroom resources

Are you a teacher? Do you want to use Star in a Box in your classroom lessons? These resources are designed to help you to explore the life-cycle of stars with your class.

  • Name the stages of a star's life-cycle, in order, for several masses of star.
  • Describe the relationship between a star's mass, its age, and its position on the Hertzsprung-Russell diagram

und.value: no-archive

Have you ever wondered how astronomers discover planets orbiting stars outside our solar system? This activity takes you through the steps astronomers use when they study extrasolar planet transits.

Interactive exoplanet data

Agent Exoplanet is an interactive web project which lets you measure the brightness of a star with a transiting planet. As the planet goes between us and the star, the planet blocks some of the light from the star. We measure this dip in brightness and see a light curve. Properties of this light curve give us information about the planet's size, mass, orbital distance and orbital speed.

Start analyzing exoplanet data!

Classroom resources

Are you a teacher? Do you want to use Agent Exoplanet in your classroom lessons? These resources are designed to help you to integrate this project into your class.

Teacher's guideview
Student worksheetview

Further reading

If you would like to know more about how stars evolve, please check out our SpaceBook pages about exrasolar planet transits.

und.value: archive

title: Using SalsaJ To Do Photometry For Extrasolar Planet Transits

und.value:
You can study extrasolar planet transits using sample data sets, data from the LCOGT observations archive, or data from Agent Exoplanet.

The videos below are screencasts taking you through the steps you need to follow as you learn to use SalsaJ and do photometry. Before viewing the screencasts, you may wish to download SalsaJ from the European Hands On Universe Website. (Until further notice, please download version 1.4, not version 2.0, which does not yet have full photometry features.)

Launch SalsaJ and download our lightcure plotter spreadsheet (you will need a spreadsheet application such as Excel, OpenOffice Spreadsheet or Numbers).

Download and unzip sample data for one of the extrasolar planets below:

  • Wasp 2b sample data - beginner
  • CoRoT 2b data set
  • Wasp 10 data set - advanced

How to choose a radius for photometry in SalsaJ:

 

How to do photometry with SalsaJ:

 

How to plot a light curve for an extrasolar planet transit:

 

Below are the main steps demonstrated by the screencast:

  1. Open the first FITS file in SalsaJ.
  2. Change the brightness as needed to view the image.
  3. Open the finder chart (a .jpg file in the folder with the sample transit data) and compare to figure out which star is the one with a transit.
  4. In SalsaJ got to Analyze -> Photometry Settings and enter your chosen star and sky radii.
  5. Enter the radii in your spreadsheet (you might need them later in case you have to redo any part of this.)
  6. Go to your spreadsheet and enter the name of the FITS file (or some unique part of it) in the Image Identifier column.
  7. In the FITS image, go to Image -> Show Info and look for the UTSTART time. Enter this time in your spreadsheet.
  8. Got to Analyze -> Photometry, then click on the star with a transit. Enter the intensity value in your spreadsheet under Target Intensity.
  9. Choose another bright star in the image (you might even want to do several separately and add extra columns to your spreadsheet for this) and click on it. Enter the intensity value in your spreasheet under Comparison Intensity.
  10. The spreadsheet divides the Target Intensity by the Comparison Intensity to adjust for any atmospheric brightening or dimming, and plots a point on the graph.
  11. Repeat steps 6-9 for each of the remaining transit images. (You will have to adjust the brightness for each one, but the photometry radii will stay the same.)

name: jbarton

und.value:
This activity, like Agent Exoplanet, allows you to use sample data to measure the change in brightness of a star as a planet passes in front of it. In this activity you will use SalsaJ, a free amateur photometry software program, to measure the brightness of the star by hand. You will then use a spreadsheet to plot your results as a graph and see if you can see your light curve.

 

Download SalsaJ from the European Hands On Universe Website.

Launch SalsaJ and download our lightcure plotter spreadsheet (you will need a spreadsheet application such as Excel, OpenOffice Spreadsheet or Numbers).

Download and unzip sample data for one of the extrasolar planets below:

  • Wasp 2b sample data - beginner
  • CoRoT 2b data set
  • Wasp 10 data set - advanced

Use the screencast below to learn how to use SalsaJ and a spreadsheet to make a light curve for a transiting exoplanet:

Below are the main steps demonstrated by the screencast:

  1. Open the first FITS file in SalsaJ
  2. Change the brightness as needed to view the image
  3. Open the finder chart (a .jpg file in the folder with the sample transit data) and compare to figure out which star is the one with a transit
  4. In SalsaJ got to Analyze -> Photometry Settings and enter your chosen star and sky radii
  5. Enter the radii in your spreadsheet (you might need them later in case you have to redo any part of this)
  6. Go to your spreadsheet and enter the name of the FITS file (or some unique part of it) in the Image Identifier column
  7. In the FITS image, go to Image -> Show Info and look for the UTSTART time. Enter this time in your spreadsheet.
  8. Got to Analyze -> Photometry, then click on the star with a transit. Enter the intensity value in your spreadsheet under Target Intensity.
  9. Choose another bright star in the image (you might even want to do several separately and add extra columns to your spreadsheet for this) and click on it. Enter the intensity value in your spreasheet under Comparison Intensity.
  10. The spreadsheet divides the Target Intensity by the Comparison Intensity to adjust for any atmospheric brightening or dimming, and plots a point on the graph.
  11. Repeat steps 6-9 for each of the remaining transit images. (You will have to adjust the brightness for each one, but the photometry radii will stay the same)
  12. You may need to double click on the Intensity axis of your spreadsheet and change the scale in order to see the light curve.

You will end up with a spreadsheet looking something like this:

[[{"type":"media","view_mode":"media_large","fid":"1501","attributes":{"class":"media-image","id":"3","typeof":"foaf:Image"}}]]

The dip in the graph shows how the planet was temporarily blocking the light from the star and decreasing the observed brightness as it orbited in front of the star.

You will then use a spreadsheet to plot your results as a graph and see if you can see your light curve.

CubeSats and their smaller cousins PocketQubs are tiny satellites which orbit the Earth in a LEO (Low Earth Orbit between 200km and 2000km). CubeSats are 10cm x 10cm x 10cm in size and PocketQubs are 4.3 cmx 4.3 cm x 4.3 cm. They transmit data constantly from around the globe but can only have this information downloaded when passing over a ground station. CubeSats and PocketQubs have been launched into orbit by many different individuals and organizations (recently UKSEDS launched a PocketQub with the help of UK Space Agency) and they survive between 12 and 18 months in orbit before they re-enter the atmosphere of Earth and burn up.

We are constructing groundstations at 4 of our observatory sites which can recieve signals from these CubeSats. A groundstation is like an antenna, picking up the Satellites signal and downloading the payload information. The payload can be anything from a camera to a specially designed experiment, as long as it fits inside the CubeSat!

Below are are some resources which will help you download information from these small satellites and through them explore space:

 Document format

Calculating the temperature of the Sun - Teacher notesWord
